title: 106_s60
content: The "Enhanced Savings Opportunities Act" is the short title of the Act. It aims to provide equitable treatment for contributions of employees to defined contribution plans under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act aims to provide equitable treatment for employee contributions to defined contribution plans by amending certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act aims to provide equitable treatment for employee contributions to defined contribution plans by amending certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including changes to sections 404(a)(10)(B), 415(a)(2), and 415(c)(3) related to exclusion allowances and annuity contracts. The Act aims to amend sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 related to defined contribution plans, including changes to exclusion allowances and annuity contracts. This includes adjustments to section 415(c) regarding contributions by church plans. The amendment to section 415(e)(5) sets limits on contributions to annuity contracts or retirement income accounts under section 403(b). Annual additions for a participant cannot exceed $10,000 and the total aggregate limit for all years is $40,000. Section 415(e)(5) is amended to remove certain provisions, section 415(n)(2)(B) is amended by striking a word, and section 402(g)(7) is amended to include a specific reference. Special rules for sections 403(b) and 408 are also added. Special rules for sections 403(b) and 408 state that annuity contracts under section 403(b) and contributions to a simplified employee pension plan are treated as defined contribution plans. Additionally, section 457(b)(2) imposes a salary limitation on eligible deferred compensation for state and local governments and tax-exempt organizations. The amendment to the salary limitation on eligible deferred compensation plans increases the limit from 33⅓ percent to 100 percent. The effective dates for the amendments are after December 31, 1999, with special rules for sections 403(b) and 408 applying after December 31, 2000. The amendment exempts elective deferrals from certain limitations under Section 404, effective for years starting after December 31, 1999.
